Title: Association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: Zhuoma Deji, Peng Liu, Xin Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuehua Luo, Zhenzhen Huang
Supporting quotes for "Reporting guideli:
- "The inclusion criteria of studies that eligible for meta-analysis were:

(1) original observational studies, such as case-control, cross-sectional or cohort studies; (2) the participants of interest of the studies were pregnant women; (3) studies that measured exposures to PFASs (PFOS, PFOA, and so on) in biological samples such as blood, from either pregnant women or the umbilical cord; (4) studies that presented pregnancy outcomes as miscarriage, stillbirth, preterm birth, pregnancy loss;

(5) studies that gave the quantitative estimates on the associations between PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as OR, relative risk (RR), or hazard ratio (HR) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs)."
  - "According to the PRISMA guidelines, a total of 1438 articles were identified from three databases, among which 1201 were excluded after preliminary screening (unrelated to study topic or duplicates)."
  - "The systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria (Fig. 1 ) (Ziegler et al., 2011)."
Reasoning for "Reporting guideline":
The paper states that the systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (MOOSE) consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria:

"The systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria (Fig. 1 ) (Ziegler et al., 2011)."

"According to the PRISMA guidelines, a total of 1438 articles were identified from three databases, among which 1201 were excluded after preliminary screening (unrelated to study topic or duplicates)."

"The inclusion criteria of studies that eligible for meta-analysis were: (1) original observational studies, such as case-control, cross-sectional or cohort studies; (2) the participants of interest of the studies were pregnant women; (3) studies that measured exposures to PFASs (PFOS, PFOA, and so on) in biological samples such as blood, from either pregnant women or the umbilical cord; (4) studies that presented pregnancy outcomes as miscarriage, stillbirth, preterm birth, pregnancy loss; (5) studies that gave the quantitative estimates on the associations between PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as OR, relative risk (RR), or hazard ratio (HR) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs)."

The paper clearly states that the systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the MOOSE and PRISMA guidelines, indicating that the authors followed specific reporting guidelines.

Title: The Association between ADHD and Environmental Chemicals-A Scoping Review
Authors: Sonja Moore, Laura Paalan, Lisa Melym, Andromachi Katsonouri, Marike Kolossa-Gehring, Hanna Tolonen
Supporting quotes for "Reporting guideli:
- "The literature searches were not conducted in a manner that fulfilled the criteria of a systematic review. This is a scoping literature review [14], which summarizes epidemiological studies on the associations of ADHD and HBM4EU priority substances, or their possible associations, which justify further research."
  - "It was difficult to make precise conclusions in terms of the strength of evidence of association between certain chemicals and ADHD. It was particularly challenging to distinguish between 'limited' and 'low' evidence."
  - "The inclusion criteria and other methods of the included reviews varied. Furthermore, many reviews highlighted the heterogeneity of the individual studies. The quality of the studies included in the reviews was also variable."
Reasoning for "Reporting guideline":
The paper does not explicitly state that it followed a specific reporting guideline. There are no mentions of the authors using a predefined checklist or guideline for reporting the scoping review.

"The literature searches were not conducted in a manner that fulfilled the criteria of a systematic review. This is a scoping literature review [14], which summarizes epidemiological studies on the associations of ADHD and HBM4EU priority substances, or their possible associations, which justify further research."
"The inclusion criteria and other methods of the included reviews varied. Furthermore, many reviews highlighted the heterogeneity of the individual studies. The quality of the studies included in the reviews was also variable."
"It was difficult to make precise conclusions in terms of the strength of evidence of association between certain chemicals and ADHD. It was particularly challenging to distinguish between 'limited' and 'low' evidence."

These quotes indicate that the authors did not follow a specific reporting guideline for this scoping review, and instead acknowledge the limitations and challenges in synthesizing the evidence from the included reviews.
